comment.text: Catalyzes the transfer of a methyl group from methyl-cobalamin to homocysteine, yielding enzyme-bound cob(I)alamin and methionine. Subsequently, remethylates the cofactor using methyltetrahydrofolate (By similarity).
Amino-acid biosynthesis; L-methionine biosynthesis via de novo pathway; L-methionine from L-homocysteine (MetH route): step 1/1.
Monomer (PubMed:17288554). Dimer (PubMed:17288554). Mainly monomer. Interacts with MTRR (PubMed:17288554).
Widely expressed. Expressed at the highest levels in pancreas, heart, brain, skeletal muscle and placenta. Expressed at lower levels in lung, liver and kidney.

Modular enzyme with four functionally distinct domains. The isolated Hcy-binding domain catalyzes methyl transfer from free methylcobalamin to homocysteine. The Hcy-binding domain in association with the pterin-binding domain catalyzes the methylation of cob(I)alamin by methyltetrahydrofolate and the methylation of homocysteine. The B12-binding domain binds the cofactor. The AdoMet activation domain binds S-adenosyl-L-methionine. Under aerobic conditions cob(I)alamin can be converted to inactive cob(II)alamin. Reductive methylation by S-adenosyl-L-methionine and flavodoxin regenerates methylcobalamin (By similarity).

disease.name: Homocystinuria-megaloblastic anemia, cblG complementation type
disease.description: An autosomal recessive inborn error of metabolism resulting from defects in the cobalamin-dependent pathway that converts homocysteine to methionine. It causes delayed psychomotor development, megaloblastic anemia, homocystinuria, and hypomethioninemia.

comment.text: The disease is caused by mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.

disease.name: Neural tube defects, folate-sensitive
disease.description: The most common NTDs are open spina bifida (myelomeningocele) and anencephaly.

comment.text: Disease susceptibility is associated with variations affecting the gene represented in this entry.
L-homocysteine is bound via the zinc atom.
Belongs to the vitamin-B12 dependent methionine synthase family.

property.value: Cobalamin (Cbl, vitamin B12) transport and metabolism
Defective MTRR causes methylmalonic aciduria and homocystinuria type cblE
Defective MTR causes methylmalonic aciduria and homocystinuria type cblG

feature.description: Decreases binding to MTRR; when associated with N-1071.
Decreases binding to MTRR; when associated with E-963.
